author: Dave McGinn
title: Why are these men, down 12-2 in a playoff game, smiling?
text:
A A The outlook wasn’t brilliant for the Blue Jays on Tuesday night. In fact, it was pretty miserable. Any hope of tying the league championship series against the Kansas City Royals was long gone by the top of the ninth inning. The Jays were being pummelled 12-2 when Toronto infielder Cliff Pennington took the mound.
When they have to bring in a guy who’s never pitched in the big leagues before, some people would give in to the misery of losing. Most people would probably look away, and hope for the game to end. Not the Jays, who have made a statement as one of Major League Baseball’s most emotionally inspiring team this postseason.
Reserve players were standing in the dugout waiting to see how the 31-year-old would fare.
(Harry How/Getty Images) (Harry How/Getty Images) (Frank Gunn/The Canadian Press) Pennington’s first pitch was a 91 mph strike right down the middle. The camera cut to the Jays dugout, where it was all joy. Smiling. Clapping. Remember, this is a team getting destroyed in the playoffs.
(MLB Advanced Media) Every parent with kids who plays sports needs to sit down and watch this moment with them, if they didn’t see it on Tuesday. Even when you’re out, it doesn’t mean you must be down.
